  • Multi-prover interactive proofs , in which Arthur exchanges messages with two (or more) computationally-powerful but untrustworthy wizards.  Here, Arthur might become convinced of some mathematical statement, but only under the assumption that the wizards could not communicate with each other during the protocol.  (The usual analogy is to a police detective who puts two suspects in separate cells, to prevent them from coordinating their answers.)  Interestingly, in some multi-prover protocols, even non-communicating wizards could successfully coordinate their responses to Arthur’s challenges (and thereby convince Arthur of a falsehood) through the use of quantum entanglement .  However, other protocols are conjectured to remain sound even against entangled wizards .

  • 概率可检验的证明 ，它们是用特殊的纠错格式编码的数学证明，因此人们只需检查一下就可以确信它们的有效性10 或者20 以相关方式随机选择的位。PCP （概率可检查证明）定理 是复杂性理论的最高成就之一，它指出任何标准形式系统（如策梅洛-弗兰克尔集合论）中的任何 数学定理都可以在多项式时间内转换为可概率检查的格式。

  • Probabilistically checkable proofs , which are mathematical proofs encoded in a special error-correcting format, so that one can become confident of their validity by checking only \(10\) or \(20\) bits chosen randomly in a correlated way.  The PCP (Probabilistically Checkable Proofs) Theorem , one of the crowning achievements of complexity theory, says that any mathematical theorem, in any standard formal system such as Zermelo-Fraenkel set theory, can be converted in polynomial time into a probabilistically-checkable format.

  • 量子证明 ，这些证明的有效性取决于量子计算的输出——甚至可能是需要将特殊纠缠的“证明状态”作为输入的量子计算。因为n量子比特可能需要∼2n 与模拟经典比特不同，量子证明具有这样的特性：在可见宇宙的约束范围内，可能永远不可能列出证明中的所有“步骤”。因此，人们对被证明的数学陈述的信任程度可能取决于人们对量子力学作为物理理论的正确性的信任程度。

  • Quantum proofs , which are proofs that depend for their validity on the output of a quantum computation—possibly, even a quantum computation that requires a special entangled “proof state” fed to it as input.  Because \(n\) quantum bits might require \(\sim2^{n}\) classical bits to simulate, quantum proofs have the property that it might never be possible to list all the “ steps” that went into the proof, within the constraints of the visible universe.  For this reason, one’s belief in the mathematical statement being proved might depend on one’s belief in the correctness of quantum mechanics as a physical theory.

  • 计算合理的证明和论证 ，其有效性依赖于这样的假设：证明者只能进行多项式时间计算，以及这样一个数学猜想：为一个谎言提出一个令人信服的论据将花费证明者超过多项式时间。

  • Computationally-sound proofs and arguments , which rely for their validity on the assumption that the prover was limited to polynomial-time computations—as well as the mathematical conjecture that crafting a convincing argument for a falsehood would have taken the prover more than polynomial time.

这些新类型的证明对数学基础有何影响？它们是否只是让“本来就显而易见”的事情变得更加戏剧化：正如大卫·多伊奇在《 无限的开端》中所言 证明是发生在大脑或计算机中的物理过程，因此，无论我们对物理学的看法如何，它们都没有有效性？这些问题与需要大量计算的“传统”证明（如阿佩尔和哈肯对四色定理的证明）本质上是一样的吗？? 或者，在“数学证明”过程中，诉诸（比如说）量子力学的有效性、表观随机数的随机性或证明者缺乏某些超能力，是否代表了某种全新的定性？寻求的是哲学分析。

What implications do these new types of proof have for the foundations of mathematics?  Do they merely make more dramatic what “should have been obvious all along”: that, as David Deutsch argues in The Beginning of Infinity , proofs are physical processes taking place in brains or computers, which therefore have no validity independent of our beliefs about physics?  Are the issues raised essentially the same as those raised by “ conventional” proofs that require extensive computations, like Appel and Haken’s proof of the Four-Color Theorem ?  Or does appealing, in the course of a “mathematical proof,” to (say) the validity of quantum mechanics, the randomness of apparently-random numbers, or the lack of certain superpowers on the part of the prover represent something qualitatively new?  Philosophical analysis is sought.

复杂性、空间和时间

Complexity, Space, and Time

计算复杂性能告诉我们什么关于空间和时间的本质？第一个答案可能是“没什么”：毕竟，标准复杂性类别的定义如下磷 可以证明复杂性理论对空间维数甚至光速是有限还是无限等细节不敏感。59另一方面  ，我认为复杂性理论确实提供了关于空间和时间之间差异的见解。

What can computational complexity tell us about the nature of space and time?  A first answer might be “not much”: after all, the definitions of standard complexity classes such as \(\mathsf{P}\) can be shown to be insensitive to such details as the number of spatial dimensions, and even whether the speed of light is finite or infinite.59  On the other hand, I think complexity theory does offer insight about the differences between space and time.

可以使用多项式数量的内存（但可能是指数量的时间60 ）解决的问题称为空间，用于多项式空间。示例空间 问题包括模拟动态系统、确定正则语法是否生成所有可能的字符串，以及在双人游戏中执行最佳策略，例如 Reversi、Connect Four 和 Hex。61不难  证明空间 至少和名词解释：磷⊆名词解释⊆空间⊆经验值。 这里经验值 表示使用指数级时间可解决的问题类别，也可能使用指数级内存。62上述  每个包含都被认为是严格的，尽管目前唯一被证明是严格的是磷≠经验值，由 Hartmanis 和 Stearns 在 1965 年得出的一项重要结果 称为时间层次定理63，64。

The class of problems solvable using a polynomial amount of memory (but possibly an exponential amount of time60) is called \(\mathsf{PSPACE}\), for Polynomial Space.  Examples of \(\mathsf{PSPACE}%\) problems include simulating dynamical systems, deciding whether a regular grammar generates all possible strings, and executing an optimal strategy in two-player games such as Reversi, Connect Four, and Hex.61  It is not hard to show that \(\mathsf{PSPACE}\) is at least as powerful as \(\mathsf{NP}\): \[\mathsf{P}\subseteq\mathsf{NP}\subseteq\mathsf{PSPACE}\subseteq\mathsf{EXP}.\] Here \(\mathsf{EXP}\) represents the class of problems solvable using an exponential amount of time, and also possibly an exponential amount of memory.62  Every one of the above containments is believed to be strict, although the only one currently proved to be strict is \(\mathsf{P}\neq \mathsf{EXP}\), by an important 1965 result of Hartmanis and Stearns  called the Time Hierarchy Theorem63\(^{,}\)64.

特别要注意的是磷≠名词解释暗示磷≠空间.因此磷≠空间 虽然尚未得到证实，但按照复杂性理论的标准，这是一个非常安全的猜想。复杂性理论家们用口号的形式认为，空间比时间更有力量。

Notice, in particular, that \(\mathsf{P}\neq\mathsf{NP}\) implies \(\mathsf{P\neq PSPACE}\).  So while \(\mathsf{P\neq PSPACE}\) is not yet proved, it is an extremely secure conjecture by the standards of complexity theory.  In slogan form, complexity theorists believe that space is more powerful than time.

现在，有些人问，这种说法怎么可能与现代物理学相一致。爱因斯坦不是教过我们空间和时间只是同一结构的两个方面吗？一个直接的答案是，即使在相对论中，空间和时间也是不可互换的：空间具有正特征，而时间具有负特征。在复杂性理论中，空间和时间之间的差异表现为一个简单的事实，即你可以 反复重复使用相同的记忆单元，但不能重复使用相同的时间时刻。65

Now, some people have asked how such a claim could possibly be consistent with modern physics.  For didn’t Einstein teach us that space and time are merely two aspects of the same structure?  One immediate answer is that, even within relativity theory, space and time are not interchangeable: space has a positive signature whereas time has a negative signature.  In complexity theory, the difference between space and time manifests itself in the straightforward fact that you can reuse the same memory cells over and over, but you can’t reuse the same moments of time.65

然而，尽管这个观察听起来微不足道，但它却引出了一个有趣的想法。假设物理定律让我们回到 过去。在这种情况下，我们很自然地会想象时间会像空间一样成为一种“可重复使用的资源”——因此，任意的空间 计算将在我们的掌握之中。但这是否只是一种无谓的猜测，或者我们能否严格证明它？

Yet, as trivial as that observation sounds, it leads to an interesting thought.  Suppose that the laws of physics let us travel backwards in time.  In such a case, it’s natural to imagine that time would become a “reusable resource” just like space is—and that, as a result, arbitrary \(\mathsf{PSPACE}\) computations would fall within our grasp.  But is that just an idle speculation, or can we rigorously justify it?

封闭类时曲线

Closed Timelike Curves

哲学家和科幻迷一样，长期以来一直对封闭类时曲线 (CTC) 的可能性感兴趣，这种曲线出现在爱因斯坦广义相对论场方程的某些解中。66按照  传统理解，CTC 提出的核心哲学问题是祖父悖论。在这种情况下，你回到过去杀死自己的祖父，因此你永远不会出生，因此你的祖父没有被杀死，因此你出生了，等等。这种矛盾是否立即意味着 CTC 是不可能的？

Philosophers, like science-fiction fans, have long been interested in the possibility of closed timelike curves (CTCs), which arise in certain solutions to Einstein’s field equations of general relativity.66  On a traditional understanding, the central philosophical problem raised by CTCs is the grandfather paradox.  This is the situation where you go back in time to kill your own grandfather, therefore you are never born, therefore your grandfather is not killed, therefore you are born, and so on.  Does this contradiction immediately imply that CTCs are impossible?

不，事实并非如此：我们只能得出这样的结论：如果CTC 存在，那么物理定律必须以某种方式防止祖父悖论的出现。它们怎么能做到这一点呢？一个经典的例子是“当你回到过去试图杀死你的祖父时，枪会卡住”——或者其他一些“不可能”的事件不可避免地发生了，以保持宇宙状态的一致性。但是，为什么我们应该想象在涉及 CTC 的每个物理实验中，总是有这样一个方便的“出路”可用？通常，我们喜欢想象我们可以自由地设计一个实验，而大自然不会对实验施加条件（例如：“每把枪有时都必须卡住”），而这些条件的原因只能通过遥远或假设的事件来理解。

No, it doesn’t: we can only conclude that, if CTCs exist, then the laws of physics must somehow prevent grandfather paradoxes from arising.  How could they do so?  One classic illustration is that “when you go back in time to try and kill your grandfather, the gun jams”—or some other “ unlikely” event inevitably occurs to keep the state of the universe consistent.  But why should we imagine that such a convenient “out” will always be available, in every physical experiment involving CTCs?  Normally, we like to imagine that we have the freedom to design an experiment however we wish, without Nature imposing conditions on the experiment (for example: “every gun must jam sometimes”) whose reasons can only be understood in terms of distant or hypothetical events.

在他 1991 年的论文《接近封闭类时间线的量子力学》中，Deutsch 提出了一个消除祖父悖论的巧妙方案。特别是，他指出，只要我们假设物理定律是量子力学的（甚至只是经典概率的），每个涉及 CTC 的实验都至少有一个固定点：即一种满足实验条件的方法，以确保一致的进化。正式来说，如果年代是通过“绕 CTC 一圈”引起的从量子态到自身的映射，那么不动点就是任何量子混合态67 ρ 使得年代（ρ）=ρ. 存在这样的ρ 简单的线性代数论证可以得出。举个例子，“祖父悖论的解决”现在就是你生来就有概率1/2如果 你出生了，你就会回到过去杀死你的祖父——由此可知，你有出生的概率1/2等等。仅仅通过将状态视为概率性的（在某种意义上，它们在量子力学中必须是概率性的68 ），我们就使得宇宙的演化具有一致性。

In his 1991 paper “Quantum mechanics near closed timelike lines,” Deutsch gave an elegant proposal for eliminating grandfather paradoxes.  In particular he showed that, as long as we assume the laws of physics are quantum-mechanical (or even just classically probabilistic), every experiment involving a CTC admits at least one fixed point: that is, a way to satisfy the conditions of the experiment that ensures consistent evolution.  Formally, if \(S\) is the mapping from quantum states to themselves induced by “going around the CTC once,” then a fixed point is any quantum mixed state67 \(\rho\) such that \(S\left( \rho\right) =\rho\).  The existence of such a \(\rho\) follows from simple linear-algebraic arguments.  As one illustration, the “resolution of the grandfather paradox” is now that you are born with probability \(1/2\), and if you are born, you go back in time to kill your grandfather—from which it follows that you are born with probability \(1/2\), and so on.  Merely by treating states as probabilistic (as, in some sense, they have to be in quantum mechanics68), we have made the evolution of the universe consistent.

但 Deutsch 对 CTC 的解释至少面临三个严重困难。第一个困难是固定点可能不是唯一的：可能存在许多混合状态ρ 使得年代（ρ）=ρ，然后问题就出现了，大自然如何选择其中之一。为了说明这一点，考虑一下祖父反悖论：b∈{0，1} 绕 CTC 旋转而不发生改变。我们可以一致假设b=0， 或者b=1，或者两者的任何概率混合——与物理学中通常的情况不同，这里没有可能的边界条件可以解决模糊性。

But Deutsch’s account of CTCs faces at least three serious difficulties.  The first difficulty is that the fixed points might not be unique: there could be many mixed states \(\rho\) such that \(S\left( \rho\right) =\rho\), and then the question arises of how Nature chooses one of them.  To illustrate, consider the grandfather anti-paradox: a bit \(b\in\left\{ 0,1\right\}\) that travels around a CTC without changing.  We can consistently assume \(b=0\), or \(b=1\), or any probabilistic mixture of the two—and unlike the usual situation in physics, here there is no possible boundary condition that could resolve the ambiguity.

第二个困难，Bennett 等人指出。 ，Deutsch 的提议违反了量子混合态的统计解释。例如，如果纠缠对中的一半|0⟩一个|0⟩乙+|1⟩一个|1⟩乙2一半放在 CTC 内部，另一半留在 CTC 外部，那么寻找固定点的过程将“打破”两半之间的纠缠。作为这个问题的“补救措施”，Bennett 等人建议要求 CTC 固定点ρ 独立于整个宇宙。在我看来，这种补救措施太过激进，基本上等于将 CTC 定义得不存在！

The second difficulty, pointed out Bennett et al. , is that Deutsch’s proposal violates the statistical interpretation of quantum mixed states. So for example, if half of an entangled pair \[\frac{\left\vert 0\right\rangle _{A}\left\vert 0\right\rangle _{B}+\left\vert 1\right\rangle _{A}\left\vert 1\right\rangle _{B}}{\sqrt{2}}%\] is placed inside the CTC, while the other half remains outside the CTC, then the process of finding a fixed point will “ break” the entanglement between the two halves.  As a “remedy” for this problem, Bennett et al. suggest requiring the CTC fixed point \(\rho\) to be independent of the entire rest of the universe.  To my mind, this remedy is so drastic that it basically amounts to defining CTCs out of existence!

受这些困难的激励，Lloyd 等人。  最近提出了一种完全不同的 CTC 解释，基于后选择隐形传态。Lloyd 等人的解释避免了上述两个问题——尽管可能并不奇怪，它本身也引入了其他问题。69我个人的观点是，无论它值不值得， Lloyd等人谈论的不是我理解的“真正的”CTC 这个概念，而是在某些有趣的方面模拟CTC  的后选择量子力学实验。如果物理学中有任何争议需要专家的哲学关注，那么这肯定是其中之一。

Motivated by these difficulties, Lloyd et al.  recently proposed a completely different account of CTCs, based on postselected teleportation.  Lloyd et al.’s account avoids both of the problems above—though perhaps not surprisingly, introduces other problems of its own.69  My own view, for whatever it is worth, is that Lloyd et al. are talking less about “true” CTCs as I would understand the concept, as about postselected quantum-mechanical experiments that simulate CTCs in certain interesting respects.  If there are any controversies in physics that call out for expert philosophical attention, surely this is one of them.

进化原理

The Evolutionary Principle

然而到目前为止，我们甚至还没有提到在我看来 Deutsch 的 CTC 解释的主要困难。那就是 找到一个固定点可能需要大自然解决一个天文数字般的计算问题！为了说明这一点，请考虑一个科幻场景，其中你回到过去并向他口述莎士比亚的剧本。莎士比亚感谢你为他节省了精力，逐字逐句地出版了你口述的剧本，几个世纪后剧本流传到你手中，然后你回到过去并将它们口述给莎士比亚，等等。

Yet so far, we have not even mentioned what I see as the main difficulty with Deutsch’s account of CTCs.  This is that finding a fixed point might require Nature to solve an astronomically-hard computational problem!  To illustrate, consider a science-fiction scenario wherein you go back in time and dictate Shakespeare’s plays to him.  Shakespeare thanks you for saving him the effort, publishes verbatim the plays that you dictated, and centuries later the plays come down to you, whereupon you go back in time and dictate them to Shakespeare, etc.

请注意，与祖父悖论相反，这里没有逻辑矛盾：我们讲述的故事完全一致。但大多数人还是觉得这个故事“自相矛盾”。毕竟，《哈姆雷特》不知怎么就写出来了，而没有人参与创作！正如 Deutsch敏锐地观察，如果这里有一个“悖论”，那么它不是逻辑悖论，而是计算复杂性悖论。具体来说，这个故事违反了一个常识性原则，我们可以粗略地表述如下：知识需要一个因果过程才能产生。像许多其他重要原则一样，在我们考虑违反这一原则的情况之前，这一原则可能根本不被视为“原则”！德语 称此原则为 进化原则(EP)。请注意，William Paley 的盲人钟表匠论证和 Richard Dawkins 的论证（讽刺的是）都援引了进化原则的某个版本 以及其他无神论者反对智能设计师的存在。

Notice that, in contrast to the grandfather paradox, here there is no logical contradiction: the story as we told it is entirely consistent.  But most people find the story “paradoxical” anyway.  After all, somehow Hamlet gets written, without anyone ever doing the work of writing it!  As Deutsch perceptively observed, if there is a “paradox” here, then it is not one of logic but of computational complexity.  Specifically, the story violates a commonsense principle that we can loosely articulate as follows: \[\text{\textbf{Knowledge requires a causal process to bring it into existence.}}%\] Like many other important principles, this one might not be recognized as a “principle” at all before we contemplate situations that violate it!  Deutsch  calls this principle the Evolutionary Principle (EP).  Note that some version of the EP was invoked both by William Paley’s blind-watchmaker argument, and (ironically) by the arguments of Richard Dawkins  and other atheists against the existence of an intelligent designer.

在我的调查文章中“名词解释-完整的问题和物理现实” ，我提出并捍卫了 EP 的复杂性理论类似物，我称之为名词解释 硬度假设：没有物理手段可以解决 名词解释- 在多项式时间内完成的问题。上述陈述意味着磷≠名词解释，但更强大的是它涵盖了概率计算、量子计算以及任何其他 与物理定律兼容的计算模型。参见 进行一项关于名词解释硬度假设、对该假设的反例的分析以及该假设对物理学的可能影响。

In my survey article “\(\mathsf{NP}\)-Complete Problems and Physical Reality” , I proposed and defended a complexity-theoretic analogue of the EP, which I called the \(\mathsf{NP}%\) Hardness Assumption: \[\text{\textbf{There is no physical means to solve }}\mathsf{NP}% \text{\textbf{-complete problems in polynomial time.}}%\] The above statement implies \(\mathsf{P}\neq\mathsf{NP}\), but is stronger in that it encompasses probabilistic computing, quantum computing, and any other computational model compatible with the laws of physics.  See  for a survey of recent results bearing on the \(\mathsf{NP}\) Hardness Assumption, analyses of claimed counterexamples to the assumption, and possible implications of the assumption for physics.

封闭类时曲线计算

Closed Timelike Curve Computation

但我们能否更严格地证明，封闭的时间曲线 会违反名词解释 硬度假设？事实上，现在让我们来证明，在一个可以在 CTC 内进行任意计算的宇宙中，大自然必须为 CTC 找到一个固定点，我们可以解决名词解释-仅使用多项式资源完成的问题。

But can we show more rigorously that closed timelike curves would violate the \(\mathsf{NP}\) Hardness Assumption?  Indeed, let us now show that, in a universe where arbitrary computations could be performed inside a CTC, and where Nature had to find a fixed point for the CTC, we could solve \(\mathsf{NP}\)-complete problems using only polynomial resources.

我们可以建模任何名词解释-通过函数完成问题实例f：{0，…，2n−1}→{0，1}，映射每个可能的解决方案十 到位1 如果十是有效的，或者0 如果十是无效的。（这里，为了方便起见，我们识别每个n位解决方案字符串 十 使用非负整数 十 二进制编码。）那么，我们的任务就是找到一个十∈{0，…，2n−1} 使得f（十）=1。我们只需进行一次评估即可解决这个问题f，只要我们可以运行以下计算机程序碳 在封闭的时间曲线内：

We can model any \(\mathsf{NP}\)-complete problem instance by a function \(f:\left\{ 0,\ldots,2^{n}-1\right\} \rightarrow\left\{ 0,1\right\}\), which maps each possible solution \(x\) to the bit \(1\) if \(x\) is valid, or to \(0\) if \(x\) is invalid.  (Here, for convenience, we identify each \(n\)-bit solution string \(x\) with the nonnegative integer that \(x\) encodes in binary.)  Our task, then, is to find an \(x\in\left\{ 0,\ldots,2^{n}% -1\right\}\) such that \(f\left( x\right) =1\).  We can solve this problem with just a single evaluation to \(f\), provided we can run the following computer program \(C\) inside a closed timelike curve :

Given input 十∈{0，…，2n−1}:

If f（十）=1, then output 十

Otherwise, output （十+1）模式2n

Given input \(x\in\left\{ 0,\ldots,2^{n}-1\right\}\):

If \(f\left( x\right) =1\), then output \(x\)

Otherwise, output \(\left( x+1\right) \operatorname{mod}2^{n}\)

假设至少有一个十使得f（十）=1，唯一的固定点碳——也就是说，碳的输出等于其输入——用于碳输入和输出这样一个有效的解决方案十，因此出现在碳的输出寄存器“就像变魔术一样”。（如果没有有效的解决方案，那么碳的不动点将只是均匀叠加或概率 分布 十∈{0，…，2n−1}。

Assuming there exists at least one \(x\) such that \(f\left( x\right) =1\), the only fixed points of \(C\)—that is, the only ways for \(C\)’s output to equal its input—are for \(C\) to input, and output, such a valid solution \(x\), which therefore appears in \(C\)’s output register “as if by magic.”  (If there are no valid solutions, then \(C\)’s fixed points will simply be uniform superpositions or probability distributions over all \(x\in\left\{ 0,\ldots,2^{n}-1\right\}\).)

为了扩展上述想法，John Watrous 和我 （根据 Fortnow 的建议）最近展示了一台采用 Deutsch 模型的 CTC 计算机，可以解决空间.（回想一下 空间 据信甚至大于名词解释）更令人惊讶的是，我们还证明了空间 构成了 CTC 计算机所能做的事情的极限；无论 CTC 计算机是经典计算机还是量子计算机，这都是正确的。我们的研究结果的一个结果是，关于 CTC 计算机的“天真直觉”——它们的效果是“使空间和时间等同于计算资源”——最终是正确的，尽管原因并不天真。70  第二个有趣的结果是，一旦有了封闭的时间曲线，从经典计算机切换到量子计算机就不会带来任何额外的 好处！

Extending the above idea, John Watrous and I  (following a suggestion by Fortnow) recently showed that a CTC computer in Deutsch’s model could solve all problems in \(\mathsf{PSPACE}\).  (Recall that \(\mathsf{PSPACE}%\) is believed to be even larger than \(\mathsf{NP}\).)  More surprisingly, we also showed that \(\mathsf{PSPACE}\) constitutes the limit on what can be done with a CTC computer; and that this is true whether the CTC computer is classical or quantum.  One consequence of our results is that the “naı̈ve intuition” about CTC computers—that their effect would be to “make space and time equivalent as computational resources”—is ultimately correct, although not for the naı̈ve reasons.70  A second, amusing consequence is that, once closed timelike curves are available, switching from classical to quantum computers provides no additional benefit!

重要的是要认识到，我们用 CTC 解决难题的算法并不仅仅归结为“花费大量时间寻找答案，然后将答案发送回计算机启动之前的时间”。即使在时间旅行计算机的奇特场景中，我们仍然要求 CTC内部使用的所有资源（时间、内存等）都是多项式有界的。因此，解决难题的能力完全来自因果一致性：要求大自然必须为 CTC 计算机找到某种避免祖父悖论的进化。

It is important to realize that our algorithms for solving hard problems with CTCs do not just boil down to “using huge amounts of time to find the answer, then sending the answer back in time to before the computer started.”  For even in the exotic scenario of a time travel computer, we still require that all resources used inside the CTC (time, memory, etc.) be polynomially-bounded.  Thus, the ability to solve hard problems comes solely from causal consistency: the requirement that Nature must find some evolution for the CTC computer that avoids grandfather paradoxes.

在 Lloyd 等人基于后选择的 CTC 替代解释中 困难的问题 也可以解决，尽管原因不同。特别是，基于我之前的一个结果，Lloyd 等人表明，他们的模型的功率对应于称为聚丙烯（概率多项式时间），被认为严格小于空间但严格大于 名词解释。因此，有人可能会说 Lloyd 等人的模型“改善”了计算情况，但改善幅度并不大！

In Lloyd et al.’s alternative account of CTCs based on postselection , hard problems can also be solved, though for different reasons.  In particular, building on an earlier result of mine , Lloyd et al. show that the power of their model corresponds to a complexity class called \(\mathsf{PP}\) (Probabilistic Polynomial-Time), which is believed to be strictly smaller than \(\mathsf{PSPACE}\) but strictly larger than \(\mathsf{NP}\).  Thus, one might say that Lloyd et al.’s model “improves” the computational situation, but not by much!

因此，人们可能会想：物理定律是否有办法允许 CTC 存在，同时又不打开难以置信的计算能力之门？至少还存在一种有趣的可能性，这是哲学家 Tim Maudlin 告诉我的。71也许  物理定律具有这样的特性：无论 CTC 内部执行什么计算，大自然总会有一个“出路”，既可以避免祖父悖论，又 可以避免解决困难的计算问题——类似于原始祖父悖论中的“枪卡壳”。这样的出路可能涉及（例如）小行星撞击 CTC 计算机，或者计算机因其他神秘原因而发生故障。当然， 物理世界中的任何计算机都有一些非零的故障概率，但通常我们想象故障概率可以小到可以忽略不计。然而，在大自然被迫寻找固定点的情况下，“神秘的计算机故障”可能成为常态而不是例外。

So one might wonder: is there any way that the laws of physics could allow CTCs, without opening the door to implausible computational powers?  There remains at least one interesting possibility, which was communicated to me by the philosopher Tim Maudlin.71  Maybe the laws of physics have the property that, no matter what computations are performed inside a CTC, Nature always has an “out”  that avoids the grandfather paradox, but also avoids solving hard computational problems—analogous to “the gun jamming” in the original grandfather paradox.  Such an out might involve (for example) an asteroid hitting the CTC computer, or the computer failing for other mysterious reasons.  Of course, any computer in the physical world has some nonzero probability of failure, but ordinarily we imagine that the failure probability can be made negligibly small.  However, in situations where Nature is being “ forced” to find a fixed point, maybe “ mysterious computer failures” would become the norm rather than the exception.

总而言之，我认为计算复杂性理论 改变了时间旅行所引发的哲学问题。虽然传统上讨论的重点是祖父悖论，但我们已经看到，即使在具有 CTC 的宇宙中，大自然也不乏避免逻辑不一致的方法。那么，“真正的”问题是如何摆脱在驯服祖父悖论过程中出现的其他悖论！其中最重要的可能是“计算复杂性悖论”，即名词解释- 就像魔术一样，完整解决了甚至更难的问题。

To summarize, I think that computational complexity theory changes the philosophical issues raised by time travel into the past.  While discussion traditionally focused on the grandfather paradox, we have seen that there is no shortage of ways for Nature to avoid logical inconsistencies, even in a universe with CTCs.  The “real”  problem, then, is how to escape the other paradoxes that arise in the course of taming the grandfather paradox!  Probably foremost among those is the “computational complexity paradox,”  of \(\mathsf{NP}\)-complete and even harder problems getting solved as if by magic.

经济学

Economics

在古典经济学中，代理人被建模为理性的贝叶斯代理人，他们会采取任何行动来最大化他们的预期效用 埃ω∈Ω[乌（ω）]，给出其主观概率{页ω}ω∈Ω 涵盖所有可能的状态ω72  当然，这幅漫画似乎是为了受到攻击而设计的，而且它几乎从各个角度受到了攻击。例如，人类甚至与理性的贝叶斯代理相差甚远，但正如卡尼曼和 特沃斯基所探讨的那样，人类遭受着众所周知的认知偏见  等等。此外，古典观点似乎没有留下任何批评人们的信念（即他们的先验概率）或效用函数为非理性的余地——然而，很容易编造出先验概率或效用函数，而这些先验概率或效用函数会导致几乎任何人都认为是疯狂的行为。第三个问题是，在有多个合作或竞争主体同时行动的博弈中，古典经济学保证主体的策略中至少存在一个纳什均衡。但通常的情况是存在多个均衡，因此没有一般原则可以预测哪个均衡将占上风，即使这种选择可能意味着战争与和平之间的区别。

In classical economics, agents are modeled as rational, Bayesian agents who take whatever actions will maximize their expected utility \(\operatorname*{E}% _{\omega\in\Omega}\left[ U\left( \omega\right) \right]\), given their subjective probabilities \(\left\{ p_{\omega}\right\} _{\omega\in\Omega}%\) over all possible states \(\omega\) of the world.72  This, of course, is a caricature that seems almost designed to be attacked, and it has been attacked from almost every angle.  For example, humans are not even close to rational Bayesian agents, but suffer from well-known cognitive biases, as explored by Kahneman and Tversky  among others.  Furthermore, the classical view seems to leave no room for critiquing people’s beliefs (i.e., their prior probabilities) or their utility functions as irrational—yet it is easy to cook up prior probabilities or utility functions that would lead to behavior that almost anyone would consider insane.  A third problem is that, in games with several cooperating or competing agents who act simultaneously, classical economics guarantees the existence of at least one Nash equilibrium among the agents’ strategies.  But the usual situation is that there are multiple equilibria, and then there is no general principle to predict which equilibrium will prevail, even though the choice might mean the difference between war and peace.

计算复杂性理论可以促进关于经济学基础的争论，因为它表明，即使在理性主体都拥有关于世界状态的完美信息的理想情况下，这些主体按照古典经济学行事往往在计算上是难以解决的。当然，这种观察的某些版本在经济学中早已得到认可。关于 有限理性的文献很多（可以追溯到赫伯特·西蒙的作品 限制性经济学（英语：Delimited Economy）是研究决策能力受到某种限制的经济主体的行为的学科。

Computational complexity theory can contribute to debates about the foundations of economics by showing that, even in the idealized situation of rational agents who all have perfect information about the state of the world, it will often be computationally intractable for those agents to act in accordance with classical economics.  Of course, some version of this observation has been recognized in economics for a long time.  There is a large literature on bounded rationality (going back to the work of Herbert Simon ), which studies the behavior of economic agents whose decision-making abilities are limited in one way or another.

有限理性与重复囚徒困境

Bounded Rationality and the Iterated Prisoners’ Dilemma

作为从这些文献中得出的一个见解的例子，请考虑有限迭代囚徒困境。这是一个两个玩家相遇固定回合数的游戏否，这是有限且玩家之间共同的知识。在每一轮中，两个玩家都可以“背叛”或“合作”（不知道对方的选择），之后他们会得到以下收益：% \begin{tabular} [c]{lll} & 缺陷$_{2}$ & 合作$_{2}$ \\ 缺陷$_{1}$ & $1,1$ & $4,0$ \\ 合作$_{1}$ & $0,4$ & $3,3$ % \end{tabular} \ \% \begin{tabular} [c]{lll} & 缺陷$_{2}$ & 合作$_{2}$ \\ 缺陷$_{1}$ & $1,1$ & $4,0$ \\ 合作$_{1}$ & $0,4$ & $3,3$ % \end{tabular} \ \两位玩家都记得之前互动的整个历史。很明显，如果双方合作，双方都会获得最佳结果，但同样清楚的是，如果否=1，那么合作就不是一个均衡。另一方面， 如果轮数 否 是未知的或无限的，那么玩家可以理性地决定合作，就像人类在现实生活中决定合作一样。也就是说，玩家 1 认为如果他背叛，那么玩家 2 会在未来的轮次中以背叛进行报复，反之亦然。因此从长远来看，双方通过合作对自己最有利。

As one example of an insight to emerge from this literature, consider the Finite Iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma.  This is a game where two players meet for some fixed number of rounds \(N\), which is finite and common knowledge between the players.  In each round, both players can either “Defect” or “ Cooperate” (not knowing the other player’s choice), after which they receive the following payoffs: \[% \begin{tabular} [c]{lll} & Defect$_{2}$ & Cooperate$_{2}$ \\ Defect$_{1}$ & $1,1$ & $4,0$ \\ Cooperate$_{1}$ & $0,4$ & $3,3$ % \end{tabular} \ \ \] Both players remember the entire previous history of the interaction.  It is clear that the players will be jointly best off if they both cooperate, but equally clear that if \(N=1\), then cooperation is not an equilibrium.  On the other hand, if the number of rounds \(N\) were unknown or infinite, then the players could rationally decide to cooperate, similarly to how humans decide to cooperate in real life.  That is, Player 1 reasons that if he defects, then Player 2 will retaliate by defecting in future rounds, and vice versa.  So over the long run, both players do best for themselves by cooperating.

现在的“悖论”是，一旦否被人知道后，上述推理就不成立了。因为假设玩家是理性的，他们都意识到，不管怎样，在这一轮中背叛也不会有什么损失。 否——因此他们就会这么做。但由于双方都知道双方都会在下一轮背叛否，双方都不会因为背叛而失去什么否−1 两者都不是——他们可以继续以这种方式归纳回到第一轮。因此，我们得到了“预测”，即双方都会在每一轮中背叛，尽管这既不符合双方的利益，也不是实际人类在实验中所做的。

The “paradox” is now that, as soon as \(N\) becomes known, the above reasoning collapses.  For assuming the players are rational, they both realize that whatever else, neither has anything to lose by defecting in round \(N\)—and therefore that is what they do.  But since both players know that both will defect in round \(N\), neither one has anything to lose by defecting in round \(N-1\) either—and they can continue inductively in this way back to the first round.  We therefore get the “prediction” that both players will defect in every round, even though that is neither in the players’ own interests, nor what actual humans do in experiments.

1985 年，奈曼 提出了一个巧妙的解决方案。具体来说，他表明，如果两个玩家的记忆足够小——从技术上讲，如果他们是有限自动机，钾 各州，2≤钾<否—那么合作再次成为一种平衡！基本的直觉是，如果两个玩家都没有足够的记忆来计算否，并且他们都知道这一点，并且他们都知道他们都知道这一点，依此类推，那么最后一段中的归纳论证就失败了，因为它假设了任何一方都无法实施的中间策略。

In 1985, Neyman proposed an ingenious resolution of this paradox.  Specifically, he showed that if the two players have sufficiently small memories—technically, if they are finite automata with \(k\) states, for \(2\leq k<N\)—then cooperation becomes an equilibrium once again!  The basic intuition is that, if both players lack enough memory to count up to \(N\), and both of them know that, and both know that they both know that, and so on, then the inductive argument in the last paragraph fails, since it assumes intermediate strategies that neither player can implement.

虽然复杂性考虑战胜了古典经济学的一些违反直觉的结论，但对我来说同样有趣的是，它们并没有战胜其他结论。举个例子，我在 罗伯特·奥曼著名的一致性定理 — 具有共同先验的完美贝叶斯代理永远不会“同意不同意” — 即使在代理之间沟通有限的情况下也能坚持下去。

While complexity considerations vanquish some of the counterintuitive conclusions of classical economics, equally interesting to me is that they do not vanquish others.  As one example, I showed in  that Robert Aumann’s celebrated agreement theorem —perfect Bayesian agents with common priors can never “agree to disagree”—persists even in the presence of limited communication between the agents.

有限理性文献中还有许多其他有趣的结果，太多了，无法在此一一列举（但请参阅鲁宾斯坦 调查）。另一方面，“有限理性”则是一个包罗万象的术语，涵盖了几乎所有可以想象到的偏离理性的行为——包括人类的认知偏差、信息收集和交流的限制，以及将策略限制在特定形式（例如线性阈值函数）中。其中许多偏差与计算复杂性本身关系不大。因此，问题仍然是计算复杂性是否能为经济行为提供新的见解。

There are many other interesting results in the bounded rationality literature, too many to do them justice here (but see Rubinstein  for a survey).  On the other hand, “ bounded rationality” is something of a catch-all phrase, encompassing almost every imaginable deviation from rationality—including human cognitive biases, limits on information-gathering and communication, and the restriction of strategies to a specific form (for example, linear threshold functions).  Many of these deviations have little to do with computational complexity per se.  So the question remains of whether computational complexity specifically can provide new insights about economic behavior.

均衡的复杂性

The Complexity of Equilibria

最近的进展表明答案是肯定的。考虑寻找双人博弈中的均衡问题，给定n×n收益矩阵作为输入。在零和博弈的特殊情况下（冯·诺依曼于 1928 年研究过），人们早就知道如何在时间多项式中解决这个问题n例如通过简化为线性规划。但在 2006 年，Daskalakis、Goldberg 和 Papadimitriou （经 Chen 和 Deng 改进）证明了一个惊人的结果：对于一般的（不一定是零和的）双人游戏来说，找到纳什均衡是“聚丙烯酰胺凝胶电泳-完成。”这里聚丙烯酰胺凝胶电泳（“多项式奇偶性论证，定向”）粗略地说，是所有搜索问题 的一个类别，对于这些问题，由于相同的组合原因， 保证存在解决方案，即每个游戏至少有一个纳什均衡。请注意，找到纳什均衡不可能名词解释- 完成，由于技术原因名词解释是一类决策问题，而决策问题“这个游戏是否存在纳什均衡？”的答案总是肯定的。但 Daskalakis 等人的结果（非正式地）表明， 寻找纳什问题的搜索问题“尽可能接近名词解释-尽可能完整”，但其决策版本是微不足道的。类似聚丙烯酰胺凝胶电泳- 完整性结果现在已为其他基本经济问题所熟知，例如在 Arrow-Debreu 市场中寻找市场清算价格。

There are some very recent advances suggesting that the answer is yes.  Consider the problem of finding an equilibrium of a two-player game, given the \(n\times n\) payoff matrix as input.  In the special case of zero-sum games (which von Neumann studied in 1928), it has long been known how to solve this problem in an amount of time polynomial in \(n\), for example by reduction to linear programming.  But in 2006, Daskalakis, Goldberg, and Papadimitriou  (with improvements by Chen and Deng ) proved the spectacular result that, for a general (not necessarily zero-sum) two-player game, finding a Nash equilibrium is “\(\mathsf{PPAD}\)-complete.”  Here \(\mathsf{PPAD}\) (“Polynomial Parity Argument, Directed”) is, roughly speaking, the class of all search problems for which a solution is guaranteed to exist for the same combinatorial reason that every game has at least one Nash equilibrium.  Note that finding a Nash equilibrium cannot be \(\mathsf{NP}\) -complete, for the technical reason that \(\mathsf{NP}\) is a class of decision problems, and the answer to the decision problem “does this game have a Nash equilibrium?”  is always yes.  But Daskalakis et al.’s result says (informally) that the search problem of finding a Nash problem is “as close to \(\mathsf{NP}\)-complete as it could possibly be,”  subject to its decision version being trivial.  Similar \(\mathsf{PPAD}%\)-completeness results are now known for other fundamental economic problems, such as finding market-clearing prices in Arrow-Debreu markets .

当然，人们可以争论这些结果的经济相关性：例如，我们现在知道73经济均衡定理中固有的计算难度在实践中实际上有多少次出现？但人们也可以同样争论均衡定理本身的经济相关性！在我看来，如果纳什均衡存在的定理 被认为与（比如说）自由市场与政府干预的辩论有关，那么 找到这些均衡的定理聚丙烯酰胺凝胶电泳-complete 也应被视为相关的。

Of course, one can debate the economic relevance of these results: for example, how often does the computational hardness that we now know73 to be inherent in economic equilibrium theorems actually rear its head in practice?  But one can similarly debate the economic relevance of the equilibrium theorems themselves!  In my opinion, if the theorem that Nash equilibria exist is considered relevant to debates about (say) free markets versus government intervention, then the theorem that finding those equilibria is \(\mathsf{PPAD}\)-complete should be considered relevant also.

结论

Conclusions

本文旨在说明如何通过考虑计算复杂性理论来丰富哲学，就像近一个世纪前通过考虑可计算性理论来丰富哲学一样。特别是，我认为计算复杂性为达尔文主义的解释内容、数学知识和证明的性质、计算主义、语法与语义、逻辑全知问题、围绕图灵测试和中文房间的争论、归纳问题、量子力学的基础、封闭类时曲线和经济理性提供了新的见解。

The purpose of this essay was to illustrate how philosophy could be enriched by taking computational complexity theory into account, much as it was enriched almost a century ago by taking computability theory into account.  In particular, I argued that computational complexity provides new insights into the explanatory content of Darwinism, the nature of mathematical knowledge and proof, computationalism, syntax versus semantics, the problem of logical omniscience, debates surrounding the Turing Test and Chinese Room, the problem of induction, the foundations of quantum mechanics, closed timelike curves, and economic rationality.

事实上，有人可能会说“真正的”问题是哪些哲学问题没有重要的计算复杂性方面！我个人的观点是，可能存在这样 的问题（即使在分析哲学中），一个很好的候选者是我们应该把什么当作“数学现实的基石”：即一组客观上正确或错误的数学陈述，无论它们是否可以在给定的形式系统中被证明或反驳。对我来说，如果我们不愿意说给定的图灵机米 要么接受，要么拒绝，要么永远运行（当在空白磁带上启动时）——并且它所做的是客观事实，独立于我们的形式公理理论、物理定律、人脑生物学、文化习俗等——那么我们就没有基础去谈论任何其他东西（公理理论、物理定律等）。此外，米的资源需求在这里无关紧要：即使米 仅在之后停止2210000 步骤，其输出在数学上是确定的，就像它在之后停止一样10步骤。74

Indeed, one might say that the “real”  question is which philosophical problems don’t have important computational complexity aspects!  My own opinion is that there probably are such problems (even within analytic philosophy), and that one good candidate is the problem of what we should take as “ bedrock mathematical reality”: that is, the set of mathematical statements that are objectively true or false, regardless of whether they can be proved or disproved in a given formal system.  To me, if we are not willing to say that a given Turing machine \(M\) either accepts, rejects, or runs forever (when started on a blank tape)—and that which one it does is an objective fact, independent of our formal axiomatic theories, the laws of physics, the biology of the human brain, cultural conventions, etc.—then we have no basis to talk about any of those other things (axiomatic theories, the laws of physics, and so on).  Furthermore, \(M\)’s resource requirements are irrelevant here: even if \(M\) only halts after \(2^{2^{10000}}\) steps, its output is as mathematically definite as if it had halted after \(10\) steps.74

我们能否概括地说明计算复杂性视角在哲学中何时有用，何时无用？从本文中的例子推断，我认为当我们想知道某个事实是否有任何解释作用时，计算复杂性往往会有所帮助：第[EVOL]、[INTEGERS]、[AI]、[WATERFALLS]和[PAC]节  都提供了这方面的例子。复杂性理论的其他“哲学应用”来自进化原理和名词解释难度假设在第[EP]节中讨论。  如果我们相信某些问题在计算上是难以解决的，那么我们可能能够从这种信念中得出关于经济合理性、量子力学、封闭时间曲线的可能性和其他问题的有趣结论。相比之下， 当我们只想知道某个事实是否“决定”另一个事实，而不关心推理链的长度时，计算复杂性往往毫无用处。

Can we say anything general about when a computational complexity perspective is helpful in philosophy, and when it isn’t?  Extrapolating from the examples in this essay, I would say that computational complexity tends to be helpful when we want to know whether a particular fact does any explanatory work: Sections [EVOL], [INTEGERS], [AI], [WATERFALLS], and [PAC] all provided examples of this.  Other “philosophical applications” of complexity theory come from the Evolutionary Principle and the \(\mathsf{NP}\) Hardness Assumption discussed in Section [EP].  If we believe that certain problems are computationally intractable, then we may be able to draw interesting conclusions from that belief about economic rationality, quantum mechanics, the possibility of closed timelike curves, and other issues.  By contrast, computational complexity tends to be unhelpful when we only want to know whether a particular fact “ determines” another fact, and don’t care about the length of the inferential chain.

对复杂性理论的批评

Criticisms of Complexity Theory

尽管复杂性理论具有广泛的解释范围，但它仍因各种原因受到批评。以下是最常见的四种批评：

Despite its explanatory reach, complexity theory has been criticized on various grounds.  Here are four of the most common criticisms:

  1. 复杂性理论只做出渐近陈述（关于解决规模问题实例所需的资源如何n缩放为n趋于无穷大）。但从逻辑上讲，渐近语句不需要对有限值有任何影响n（说，10，000) 是人类真正关心的问题，任何有限量的实验数据都无法证实或反驳渐近断言。

  2. Complexity theory only makes asymptotic statements (statements about how the resources needed to solve problem instances of size \(n\) scale as \(n\) goes to infinity).  But as a matter of logic, asymptotic statements need not have any implications whatsoever for the finite values of \(n\) (say, \(10,000\)) that humans care actually about, nor can any finite amount of experimental data confirm or refute an asymptotic claim.

  3. 复杂性理论的许多基本原理（我们希望如此）如下：磷≠名词解释，目前都是尚未得到证实的数学猜想，并且很可能在很长一段时间内仍将保持这种状态。

  4. Many of (what we would like to be) complexity theory’s basic principles, such as \(\mathsf{P}\neq\mathsf{NP}\), are currently unproved mathematical conjectures, and will probably remain that way for a long time.

  5. 复杂性理论仅关注有限类型的计算机——串行、确定性图灵机——并且未能包含自然界中发现的“更混乱”的计算现象。

  6. Complexity theory focuses on only a limited type of computer—the serial, deterministic Turing machine—and fails to incorporate the “messier” computational phenomena found in nature.

  7. 复杂性理论仅研究算法的最坏情况行为，并未解决该行为是否具有代表性，或者是否仅仅反映了一些“病态”输入。因此，即使 磷≠名词解释，可能仍然有很好的启发式方法来解决大多数情况名词解释- 完成实践中实际出现的问题；复杂性理论没有告诉我们有关这种可能性的任何信息。

  8. Complexity theory studies only the worst-case behavior of algorithms, and does not address whether that behavior is representative, or whether it merely reflects a few “ pathological” inputs.  So for example, even if \(\mathsf{P}% \neq\mathsf{NP}\), there might still be excellent heuristics to solve most instances of \(\mathsf{NP}\)-complete problems that actually arise in practice; complexity theory tells us nothing about such possibilities one way or the other.

不管怎样，批评 (3) 和 (4) 自 20 世纪 80 年代以来已经变得不那么准确了。正如本文所讨论的，复杂性理论现在已经远远超出了确定性图灵机的范围，包括（例如）量子力学、并行和分布式计算以及达尔文进化等随机过程。与此同时，尽管最坏情况的复杂性仍然是最容易理解的一种，但今天有大量的工作——其中大部分是由密码学推动的——研究计算问题的平均难度，针对输入的各种概率分布。正如几乎所有复杂性理论家都相信磷≠名词解释，因此几乎所有人都更坚信存在 平均水平的 名词解释问题——事实上，这种信念是现代密码学的基础之一。一些问题，例如计算离散对数，甚至已知对随机输入的难度与对最难的输入的难度一样大 （尽管这种“最坏情况/平均情况等价性”是否适用于任何名词解释完全问题仍然是一个悬而未决的主要问题）。出于这些原因，尽管谈论平均情况而不是最坏情况的复杂性会使本文中的一些论点复杂化，但我认为这不会对结论产生太大影响。75参见  Bogdanov 和 Trevisan近期对平均案例复杂性的出色调查，以及 Impagliazzo就复杂性理论的“可能世界”展开了一场令人回味的讨论（例如， 名词解释- 完整的问题在最坏的情况下会变得很难，但平均而言很容易）。

For whatever it’s worth, criticisms (3) and (4) have become much less accurate since the 1980s.  As discussed in this essay, complexity theory has by now branched out far beyond deterministic Turing machines, to incorporate (for example) quantum mechanics, parallel and distributed computing, and stochastic processes such as Darwinian evolution.  Meanwhile, although worst-case complexity remains the best-understood kind, today there is a large body of work—much of it driven by cryptography—that studies the average-case hardness of computational problems, for various probability distributions over inputs.  And just as almost all complexity theorists believe that \(\mathsf{P}\neq\mathsf{NP}\), so almost all subscribe to the stronger belief that there exist hard-on-average \(\mathsf{NP}\) problems—indeed, that belief is one of the underpinnings of modern cryptography.  A few problems, such as calculating discrete logarithms, are even known to be just as hard on random inputs as they are on the hardest possible input (though whether such “ worst-case/average-case equivalence” holds for any \(\mathsf{NP}\)-complete problem remains a major open question).  For these reasons, although speaking about average-case rather than worst-case complexity would complicate some of the arguments in this essay, I don’t think it would change the conclusions much.75  See Bogdanov and Trevisan for an excellent recent survey of average-case complexity, and Impagliazzo for an evocative discussion of complexity theory’s “possible worlds” (for example, the “world” where \(\mathsf{NP}\)-complete problems turn out to be hard in the worst case but easy on average).

更广泛的观点是，即使我们承认批评 (1)-(4) 有道理，这并不意味着我们可以在不喜欢复杂性理论论证时将其驳回！在科学中，我们只处理不完善的近似理论——如果我们拒绝某个领域最佳近似理论的结论，那么我们就有责任解释原因。

The broader point is that, even if we admit that criticisms (1)-(4) have merit, that does not give us a license to dismiss complexity-theoretic arguments whenever we dislike them!  In science, we only ever deal with imperfect, approximate theories—and if we reject the conclusions of the best approximate theory in some area, then the burden is on us to explain why.

举例来说，假设你认为量子计算机在解决任何实际问题时都不会比传统计算机有更快的速度。那么，作为你立场的解释，你可能会断言以下任何一种观点：

To illustrate, suppose you believe that quantum computers will never give a speedup over classical computers for any practical problem.  Then as an explanation for your stance, you might assert any of the following:

  1. 量子力学是错误的或不完整的，尝试构建可扩展的量子计算机反而会导致量子力学本身的伪造或扩展。

  2. Quantum mechanics is false or incomplete, and an attempt to build a scalable quantum computer would instead lead to falsifying or extending quantum mechanics itself.

  3. 存在多项式时间经典算法来分解整数，以及所有其他允许多项式时间量子算法的问题。（从复杂性的角度来看，类别 布隆迪和边界量子协议是相等的。

  4. There exist polynomial-time classical algorithms for factoring integers, and for all the other problems that admit polynomial-time quantum algorithms.  (In complexity terms, the classes \(\mathsf{BPP}\) and \(\mathsf{BQP}\) are equal.)

  5. 对于任何可以想象的人类感兴趣的问题来说，构建量子计算机所涉及的“常数因子开销”非常大，以至于抵消了它们的渐近优势。

  6. The “constant-factor overheads”  involved in building a quantum computer are so large as to negate their asymptotic advantages, for any problem of conceivable human interest.

  7. 虽然我们还不知道（a）-（c）中的哪一个成立，但我们可以根据一些先验依据知道至少其中有一个必须成立。

  8. While we don’t yet know which of (a)-(c) holds, we can know on some a priori ground that at least one of them has to hold.

关键在于，即使我们无法回答复杂性理论分析的所有可能缺陷，我们仍然可以用它来澄清选择：迫使人们摊牌，要么承诺一个可能被证伪的预测，要么承诺一个可能被推翻的数学猜想。当然，这是所有科学理论的共同特征，而不是复杂性理论所特有的。如果复杂性理论在这里与众不同，那也只是因为它所处理的“预测”数量可以通过数学证明（事实上，只有通过数学证明）来证实或反驳。76

The point is that, even if we can’t answer every possible shortcoming of a complexity-theoretic analysis, we can still use it to clarify the choices: to force people to lay some cards on the table, committing themselves either to a prediction that might be falsified or to a mathematical conjecture that might be disproved.  Of course, this is a common feature of all scientific theories, not something specific to complexity theory.  If complexity theory is unusual here, it is only in the number of “predictions” it juggles that could be confirmed or refuted by mathematical proof (and indeed, only by mathematical proof).76

未来方向

Future Directions

即使对复杂性理论的各种批评并不否定其相关性，直面这些批评也是很好的——更广泛地说，更清楚地理解复杂性理论与它试图解释的现实世界现象之间的关系。为此，我认为以下问题都将受益于仔细的哲学分析：

Even if the various criticisms of complexity theory don’t negate its relevance, it would be great to address those criticisms head-on—and more generally, to get a clearer understanding of the relationship between complexity theory and the real-world phenomena that it tries to explain.  Toward that end, I think the following questions would all benefit from careful philosophical analysis:

  • 渐近论断的经验地位如何？对于“做出预测”或由有限数量的观察结果支持或排除的渐近论断，我们能给出什么意义？

  • What is the empirical status of asymptotic claims?  What sense can we give to an asymptotic statement “making predictions,” or being supported or ruled out by a finite number of observations?

  • 我们如何解释复杂性理论所依赖的经验事实：例如，我们很少看到n10000 或者1.0000001n算法，或者人类关心的计算问题倾向于将自身组织成相对较少数量的等价类？

  • How can we explain the empirical facts on which complexity theory relies: for example, that we rarely see \(n^{10000}\) or \(1.0000001^{n}\) algorithms, or that the computational problems humans care about tend to organize themselves into a relatively-small number of equivalence classes?

  • 在没有证据的情况下，人们如何形成关于数学猜想的真假的直觉？在以下情况下，这些直觉是什么？磷≠名词解释？

  • Short of proof, how do people form intuitions about the truth or falsehood of mathematical conjectures?  What are those intuitions, in cases such as \(\mathsf{P}\neq\mathsf{NP}\)?

  • 人们有时想从猜想中得出的概念性结论是否磷≠名词解释 或者布隆迪≠边界量子协议——例如，关于数学创造力的本质或量子力学的解释——实际上取决于这些猜想是否正确？有没有更容易证明的陈述可以支持相同的结论？

  • Do the conceptual conclusions that people sometimes want to draw from conjectures such as \(\mathsf{P}\neq\mathsf{NP}\) or \(\mathsf{BPP}% \neq\mathsf{BQP}\)—for example, about the nature of mathematical creativity or the interpretation of quantum mechanics—actually depend on those conjectures being true?  Are there easier-to-prove statements that would arguably support the same conclusions?

  • 如果磷≠名词解释那么，即使在定理证明普遍难以解决的情况下，人类如何取得如此巨大的数学进步？是否存在“选择效应”，即数学家青睐具有特殊结构的问题，使其比任意问题更容易解决？如果是这样，那么这种结构由什么组成？

  • If \(\mathsf{P}\neq\mathsf{NP}\), then how have humans managed to make such enormous mathematical progress, even in the face of the general intractability of theorem-proving?  Is there a “selection effect,” by which mathematicians favor problems with special structure that makes them easier to solve than arbitrary problems?  If so, then what does this structure consist of?

简而言之，我认为与本文相反的文章有很大的发展空间：“为什么计算复杂性理论家应该关心哲学。”

In short, I see plenty of scope for the converse essay to this one: “Why Computational Complexity Theorists Should Care About Philosophy.”

致谢

Acknowledgments

我非常感谢 Oron Shagrir 鼓励我完成这篇论文，并对我提出的有益评论和第[GRUE]节的建议；感谢 Alex Byrne 对我提出的第[WATERFALLS]节的建议；感谢 Agustı́n Rayo 对我提出的第[OMNI]节的建议；以及感谢 David Aaronson、Seamus Bradley、Terrence Cole、Michael Collins、Andy Drucker、Michael Forbes、Oded Goldreich、Bob Harper、Gil Kalai、Dana Moshkovitz、Jan Arne Telle、Dylan Thurston、Ronald de Wolf、Avi Wigderson 和 Joshua Zelinsky 对我提出的反馈。

I am grateful to Oron Shagrir for pushing me to finish this essay, for helpful comments, and for suggesting Section [GRUE]; to Alex Byrne for suggesting Section [WATERFALLS]; to Agustı́n Rayo for suggesting Section [OMNI]; and to David Aaronson, Seamus Bradley, Terrence Cole, Michael Collins, Andy Drucker, Michael Forbes, Oded Goldreich, Bob Harper, Gil Kalai, Dana Moshkovitz, Jan Arne Telle, Dylan Thurston, Ronald de Wolf, Avi Wigderson, and Joshua Zelinsky for their feedback.
